         Figure 2(a): Fact file on the St Lawrence River estuary and the Gulf of St Lawrence

The St Lawrence River estuary and the Gulf of St Lawrence are recognized as a Large Ocean
Management Area by the Canadian government (Figure 2(b)).

y    It is an important shipping route from the Atlantic Ocean to eastern Canada.
y    The area is highly productive (Figure 4(a)).
y    It provides habitat for wildlife, including resident and migratory birds, whales and crabs.
y    It provides nursery grounds for commercial fish species (cod, halibut).
y   Management of the area is challenging because the interests of different stakeholders may be in
     conflict or environmentally damaging.

                  Figure 6(b): Fact file on the beluga whale (Delphinapterus leucas)

y   Opportunistic feeders, change their food sources with the seasons.
y   Can live for up to 70 years.
y   40–50 % of the beluga whale’s body weight is made up of fat.
y   Reaches sexual maturity between 5 and 9 years of age.
y   The worldwide population of beluga whales is estimated at 150 000.
y   The St Lawrence River estuary population (900 individuals)
      à is isolated from other beluga whales
      à is listed as endangered by the Canadian government
      à has been protected by law since 1983.

                                                             Figure 8: Threats to the St Lawrence River beluga whale

Shipping and whale watching:
  y Noise from ships disturbs feeding behaviour.
  y Ships may separate young whales from their mothers.

Hunting:
  • Until the 1980s, beluga whales were hunted because they competed with the commercial fishing
     industry.

Pollution:
  • Heavy metals, such as lead (Pb), mercury (Hg) and cadmium (Cd) from industrial effluent.
  • Persistent organic pollutants (POPs), such as DDT and PCBs, from agriculture and industry.
  • Treated and untreated sewage from cities along the river.
  • Microplastic beads from domestic and industrial waste.
  • Pollutants accumulate in the mud at the bottom of the river.
                                                 – 11 –               N19/4/ENVSO/SP1/ENG/TZ0/XX/T

                Figure 9(a): Fact file on the round goby (Neogobius melanostomus)

• An invasive species from Asia.
• First discovered in the St Lawrence River in 1990.
• Females lay eggs three times a year; up to 5000 eggs at a time.
• Young fish mature quickly.
• Can eat up to 4000 eggs of other fish in 15 minutes.
• Aggressively defend the best egg-laying sites, out-competing the native mottled sculpin
   (Cottus bairdii).
• Eat invasive zebra mussels.
• Eaten by native fish, such as lake trout and yellow perch.

                  Figure 10: Untreated sewage release into the St Lawrence River

Montreal:
In November 2015, the City of Montreal discharged between 5 and 8 billion litres of untreated sewage
into the St Lawrence River.
y It was called “FlushGate” in the Canadian news.
y Citizens were warned to avoid contact with the water.
y River pollution levels returned to normal within 4 to 10 days.
y The Mayor of Montreal described it as the “most environmentally-friendly solution”.

Quebec:
In November 2016, the City of Quebec discharged 110 million litres of untreated sewage into the
St Lawrence River.

Nationally:
y 25 % of Canadians do not have access to sewage or wastewater treatment centres.
y 205 billion litres of untreated sewage are released into Canadian rivers and oceans each year.

                                   [Source: adapted from www.cbc.ca/news]
